entry.title: Mexico to hike tariffs on China starting Thursday
entry.summary: Mexico's sweeping new tariffs on imports from mostly Asian countries are set to take effect on Thursday, in a move that will largely align Mexico with the U.S. as the neighboring countries place significant barriers on Chinese imports.

entry.title: Oil tankers still arriving in Venezuela despite US blockade, data shows
entry.summary: At least two oil tankers have made their way to Venezuela in recent days and others are navigating towards the country, a sign of state-run PDVSA's effort to expand floating storage and keep selling crude even as a U.S. blockade has reduced exports to a minimum.

entry.title: Air China to buy 60 Airbus planes worth $9.5 billion
entry.summary: China's flagship carrier Air China said on Tuesday that it and a subsidiary have signed an agreement with Airbus to purchase 60 A320NEO jets in a deal worth around $9.5 billion at list prices.

entry.title: China Aircraft Leasing to buy 30 Airbus A320neo aircraft
entry.summary: China Aircraft Leasing Group Holdings said on Tuesday its unit CALC (BVI) has agreed to buy 30 A320neo aircraft from Airbus .

entry.title: See the soul of Laos on this slow river cruise along the Mekong
entry.summary:
The Mekong‚Äôs earthy waters turn silver and gold around sunset, capturing a mystical essence in Laos. Slip into the slow pace of life in Laos, where a new Mekong cruise follows the river‚Äôs course past the pagoda-studded world heritage city of Luang Prabang, into a less-explored stretch of the waterway towards the capital Vientiane.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The pan-roasted poop of the mulberry tree worm, it turns out, tastes like smoky green tea. This I learn sitting in the shade of a fiery-yellow flowering srisuk ‚Äòhappiness‚Äô tree, sipping the scat infused in hot water. ‚ÄúI discovered this when I saw one of my team collecting it,‚Äù says Veomanee (Veo) Douangdala. At first, her colleague was too shy to tell her what the droppings were ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How this 100-year-old sun compass unlocked polar exploration
entry.summary:
The inventor of this style of sun compass, Albert H. Bumstead, was a renowned tinkerer and the National Geographic Society's first chief cartographer. It took a National Geographic cartographer to invent a compass that worked where compasses don't.
The magnetized needle of a conventional compass wants to align with Earth‚Äôs magnetic field‚Äîhelpful, unless you‚Äôre near the poles, where the field tugs straight downward, rendering magnetic compasses useless. Pilot and National Geographic Explorer Richard E. Byrd, who hoped to fly over the North Pole in the summer of 1925, lamented this during a pre-trip address to the National Geographic Society, and his gripe sent chief cartographer Albert H. Bumstead tinkering. Bumstead developed a novel piece of hardware, a bit like a swiveling watch. Incline it to match one‚Äôs latitude and the single, 24-hour hand tracks the sun across the sky. Since the sun at northern latitudes sits due south at noon, an Arctic aviator can align the hand with the sun and set a compass dial by the timepiece. Simple. Elegant. Byrd took one to the Arctic in 1925 and again in ‚Äô26. He returned it to the cartographer engraved: ‚ÄúTo Albert H. Bumstead. For getting us there.‚Äù
See this object and more at the National Geographic Museum of Exploration starting summer 2026. Visit¬†moe.nationalgeographic.org. A version of this story appears in the January 2026 issue of National Geographic magazine.

entry.title: Why are cheetahs struggling to survive?
entry.summary:
In his new documentary special, Bertie Gregory follows cheetahs during the Great Migration in the Serengeti. Filmmaker Bertie Gregory's new documentary special captures the extreme challenges facing the world's fastest land animal.
In the world of wildlife adventure, Bertie Gregory has seemingly done it all. He‚Äôs tracked pumas in Patagonia, swum alongside great white sharks without a cage in South Africa, and camped through a frigid, six-day blizzard to observe emperor penguins in Antarctica. But up until now, he had never experienced Tanzania during the Great Migration‚Äîone of the last large-mammal migrations on Earth.
Over one million animals roam the Serengeti during this sprawling annual feat, but in his new documentary special, Cheetahs Up Close with Bertie Gregory (strea‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 night sky events to see in January
entry.summary:
A photographer captures the aurora borealis during the peak of the Quadrantid meteor shower in Hemnes, Norway, in January. The month brings a strong lineup of celestial sights, including a supermoon, meteor activity, and several close moon-planet encounters.
January doesn‚Äôt skimp on cosmic sightseeing. The month begins with a vibrant supermoon, continues with the year‚Äôs best Jupiter view, and ends with multiple moon-planet conjunctions. Aurora activity continues to look promising this January, especially with long hours of winter darkness in light-chasing getaways like Alaska and Iceland.¬†
Here‚Äôs what to watch for in the night sky this month, with tips on snagging the best view.
As the new year begins, the night sky has its own midnight marker. Sirius, the brightest sta‚Ä¶

entry.title: What we're learning about the real strength of the female body
entry.summary:
A surfer prepares for one of the worst surfing mishaps, a wipeout that would hold her underwater, by running on the ocean floor while carrying a rock, Oahu Island, Hawaii. New science is upending long held assumptions that men are physically stronger than women. From fat cells that stretch like spandex to more flexible muscles, scientists are finding that women‚Äôs bodies are just as strong as men‚Äôs.
¬†On the slopes of Mount Kilimanjaro, the air thinned to a whisper, Deborah Clegg, a metabolic physiologist with a newfound appreciation for high places, found herself unfazed by the altitude. Her stride was steady, her energy unflagging. Clegg‚Äôs climbing partner, Biff Palmer‚Äîan accomplished nephrologist and mountaineer who had summited Everest and six of the world‚Äôs tallest peaks‚Äîfound t‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to plan your first visit to Serengeti National Park
entry.summary:
Three cheetahs stand on a large rock in Serengeti National Park, the most popular tourist destination in Tanzania. If you've never been on safari before, this Tanzanian park - home to big cats, elephants and antelopes galore - is a great place to start.
A¬†perfect morning on safari¬†could begin¬†with a sunrise balloon flight, drifting over a golden savannah. Down below,¬†zebras¬†call to each other with their distinctive, braying cries. After brunch on terra firma,¬†you can¬†scan for¬†lions¬†as your 4x4 vehicle threads its way through herds of¬†wildebeests, before arriving at a comfortable camp with tents shaded by acacia, kigelia or commiphora trees.
In Tanzania‚Äôs¬†Serengeti National Park, one of East Africa‚Äôs finest safari destinations, experiences like these aren‚Äôt just possible: they‚Äô‚Ä¶

entry.title: Sudan: UN warns of unprecedented child hunger in Darfur as fighting fuels refugee exodus
entry.summary: Sudan‚Äôs deepening war is driving unprecedented levels of hunger, child malnutrition and displacement, UN agencies report, as new data from Darfur and a renewed refugee influx into Chad underscore the rapidly deteriorating situation.

entry.summary: Follow our live coverage as the General Assembly and its Fifth Committee meet today to finalize negotiations and vote on the United Nations‚Äô regular budget for 2026. The Fifth Committee is responsible for administrative and budgetary matters, including the Organization‚Äôs finances and staffing. entry.summary: Kalshi is a prediction market that aims to let users bet on everything.‚Ä¶ Tags: betting, Financial Times, Kalshi, prediction, Sam Learner, sports

entry.title: Exclusive: China mandates 50% domestic equipment rule for chipmakers
entry.summary: China is requiring chipmakers to use at least 50% domestically made equipment for adding new capacity, three people familiar with the matter said, as Beijing pushes to build a self-sufficient semiconductor supply chain.

entry.title: Thailand-Cambodia ceasefire holds, but Bangkok says breaches delayed release of prisoners
entry.summary: A renewed ceasefire between Thailand and Cambodia over border clashes passed the 72-hour mark on Tuesday, an initial goal the countries set to secure a more lasting peace, but Bangkok said it had delayed the release of 18 Cambodian soldiers due to alleged breaches of the deal.

entry.title: Belarus shows off deployment of Russian nuclear-capable Oreshnik missiles on its territory
entry.summary: Belarus on Tuesday released video of what it said was the deployment on its territory of the Russian nuclear-capable hypersonic Oreshnik missile system, a development that bolsters Moscow's ability to deliver missiles across Europe.

entry.title: South Korea's President Lee to visit China from January 4 to 7 as Seoul seeks to restore ties
entry.summary: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung will make a state visit to China from January 4 to 7 and meet Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping, the Blue House said on Tuesday, aiming to keep up momentum to restore ties.

entry.title: The 2025 energy transition in eight charts: clean wins, dirty setbacks
entry.summary: For supporters of the energy transition, 2025 had plenty to complain about: the scrapping of U.S. clean energy policies, wind droughts in Europe, corporate retreats from wind power generation and a resurgence in coal-fired power output.

entry.title: In Ireland, women celebrate their own "Christmas" in January
entry.summary:
Nollaig na mBan‚Äîotherwise known as "Women‚Äôs Christmas," "Little Christmas," or "Little Women‚Äôs Christmas"‚Äîis a tradition that modern Ireland is reviving even as traditional gender roles shift. Nollaig na mBan is an old tradition from the country's south that modern women have turned into a day to celebrate their labor during the holidays.
Christmas isn‚Äôt everyone‚Äôs favorite holiday in Ireland. For Tracey Groome, a 48-year-old deputy principal who lives in Kildorrey in County Cork, the highlight of the season is Nollaig na mBan (pronounced "Null-ig na Mahn"), also known as Women‚Äôs Christmas, Little Christmas or Little Women‚Äôs Christmas. It‚Äôs ‚Äúthe night that I get to really relax because there‚Äôs no pressure on me,‚Äù says Groome. On Nollaig na mBan, gender roles reverse and it‚Äôs a day ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Asian stocks pulled lower by tech, gold and silver cool off
entry.summary: Asian shares slipped on Tuesday, tracking Wall Street's tech slump, while silver and gold steadied after a sharp pullback from record highs took some froth off the precious metals' incredible rally.

entry.title: Dollar steady before Fed minutes, China's yuan breaches key level
entry.summary: The dollar held steady above recent lows on Tuesday ahead of the release of the minutes from the Federal Reserve's December meeting, while China's yuan strengthened through a key psychological level against the U.S. currency.

entry.title: Six China IPOs debut in Hong Kong after raising $900 million to cap banner year
entry.summary: Six Chinese companies made their Hong Kong trading debuts on Tuesday after raising about HK$6.99 billion ($900 million), with most opening above their IPO prices, rounding off a resurgent year for listings as the city dominated Asian equity capital markets.

entry.title: 20 travel adventures to book in 2026
entry.summary:
Dramatic cliffs, hidden coves and golden beaches line the Fishermen's trail in Portugal. The crackle of a campfire beneath a star-studded sky; the scent of cedar in old-growth forests; the thunder of a packed football stadium rolling through your chest ‚Äî this year‚Äôs most talked-about travel experiences engage all the senses. From stargazing in Northumberland to barefoot forest bathing in Japan and sport-fuelled escapes across South America, here‚Äôs our pick of 2026‚Äôs hottest trends.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
If travel in 2026 has a defining mood, it‚Äôs immersion ‚Äî the kind of adventures that stir something deeper within us, and that linger long after we leave a destination. And the data backs it up. UN Tourism‚Äôs latest outlook reports tha‚Ä¶

entry.title: What explains a mysterious rise in migraine attacks?
entry.summary:
A recent systematic review observed an upward trend in migraine severity in the United States. Climate change may be to blame. Weather patterns such as extreme heat and storm conditions have been linked to migraine attacks, and research shows those environmental conditions are becoming more common.
Cristian-Ovidiu Marin, 34, used to get mild migraine attacks every couple of months, usually when he was stressed out or didn‚Äôt get enough sleep. About four years ago, he began getting more¬†severe migraine flare-ups. ‚ÄúMy migraines have become more frequent and intense, often with sharp, pounding pain, nausea, and light sensitivity that wipes out my focus for several hours, sometimes the whole day,‚Äù says Marin, the CEO of an online game company based in Bucharest.
Scientific evidence‚Ä¶

entry.title: 'Java Man' returned to Indonesia
entry.summary:
Photo shows a skullcap fossil of a "Java Man" at the National Museum of Indonesia in Jakarta on Dec. 17, 2025. The fossil was recently repatriated to Indonesia from the Netherlands. The iconic Homo erectus fossil was welcomed home with a repatriation ceremony and a new museum exhibit in Jakarta.
Jakarta, IndonesiaMore than 130 years since its discovery in East Java, one of the most influential fossils in human history has finally returned home to Indonesia. The specimen, known as Java Man, transformed our understanding of own species and our ancient relatives. On December 17, through a repatriation agreement between the Netherlands and Indonesia, the fossil finished its long journey to the National Museum in Jakarta.
‚ÄúFor too long over a century, a significant part of our past‚Ä¶

entry.title: Gaza battered by heavy rains as humanitarian response continues
entry.summary: Severe weather conditions have led to further casualties and heightened health risks in Gaza over the past 24 hours, the UN aid coordination office (OCHA) reported on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Briefing on threats to international peace and security
entry.summary: The UN Security Council meets today to hear a briefing on threats to international peace and security following Israel‚Äôs recent recognition of the northern region of Somalia as an independent and sovereign state. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here and go here for all our in-depth meeting coverage.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN, US sign $2 billion humanitarian funding agreement for 17 crisis-hit countries
entry.summary: The United Nations and the United States on Monday formalized an agreement under which the US committed $2 billion in humanitarian assistance for global relief programmes, a move the UN‚Äôs top relief official hailed as a landmark commitment to saving lives amid escalating humanitarian needs worldwide.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN chief urges world leaders to ‚Äòget priorities straight‚Äô as New Year message calls for peace over war
entry.summary: As the world enters 2026 amid mounting crises, the UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres has issued a stark but hopeful New Year appeal, urging global leaders to shift resources away from destruction and towards development, peace and people.

entry.title: China to lower import tariffs on some products beginning 2026
entry.summary: China announced on Monday tariff adjustments for some products beginning next year, including lowering the import duties on resource-based commodities such as recycled black powder for lithium-ion batteries.

entry.title: China opposes recognition of Somaliland, affirms support for Somalia
entry.summary: China opposes any attempt to split territories in Somalia, the foreign ministry said on Monday, affirming Chinese support for the sovereignty, unity and territorial integrity of the East African country.

entry.title: China says it's 'seriously dissatisfied' with monument demolition in Panama
entry.summary: China is seriously dissatisfied with the demolition of a Chinese monument by the local government in Panama's Arraijan district in West Panama Province, a Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson said on Monday.

entry.title: Top diplomats of China, Cambodia and Thailand meet as Beijing seeks a stronger role in dispute
entry.summary: Foreign ministers from Cambodia and Thailand have convened with their Chinese counterpart to discuss the border dispute between the two Southeast Asian countries.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: Thailand and Cambodia agree to consolidate ceasefire in China talks
entry.summary: Thailand and Cambodia plan to rebuild mutual trust and gradually consolidate a ceasefire after weeks of border clashes, Beijing said in a communique with the two countries following talks in southwestern China.

entry.title: Exclusive: VinFast-linked GSM plans Hong Kong IPO at up to $3 billion valuation, sources say
entry.summary: Vietnamese electric-vehicle taxi operator GSM, part of the Vingroup stable of companies, plans to list in Hong Kong in what could be the first IPO in the city by a firm from the Southeast Asian nation, two sources said.

entry.title: World shares are mostly lower in quiet holiday trading as China stages war drills near Taiwan
entry.summary: Shares in Europe and Asia are mostly lower in thin holiday trading as China stages military exercises near the island of Taiwan. U.S. futures were mixed.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: China's Leapmotor targets annual sales of more than 4 million units in a decade
entry.summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker Leapmotor expects to sell more than 4 million vehicles a year within the next decade, CEO Zhu Jiangming said on Monday.

entry.title: China blames military drills for reef damage around disputed shoal
entry.summary: China said without naming any country that military activities such as bomb-dropping training in the waters around Scarborough Shoal have damaged the coral reefs there, state broadcaster CCTV said on Monday citing an ecological report.

entry.title: Stocks head for year-end record on Fed rate cut bets
entry.summary: Global stocks were on track on Monday to end 2025 at record highs, while the dollar hovered near its lowest in almost three months, reflecting expectations of further Federal Reserve interest rate cuts next year.

entry.title: China launches military drills around Taiwan amid tensions with Japan
entry.summary: China's military moved army, naval, air force and rocket force units around Taiwan for its "Just Mission 2025" drills, aimed at testing combat readiness and delivering a "stern warning" against moves toward Taiwanese independence.

entry.title: Inside Beijing's bid to tame the global iron ore market
entry.summary: China's state iron ore buyer is using increasingly hardball tactics against mining giants.

entry.title: Putin and Trump do not support European-Ukrainian temporary ceasefire idea, the Kremlin says
entry.summary: The Kremlin said on Sunday that Russian President Vladimir Putin and U.S. President Donald Trump do not support a European-Ukrainian push for a temporary ceasefire ahead of a settlement, and that Moscow thinks Kyiv needs to make a decision on Donbas.

entry.title: Technology is transforming travel and here's what's next
entry.summary:
Trolltunga in Norway has seen a surge in visitors in the past decade after featuring in social media posts. For better or worse, advancements in tech are transforming our trips. We look at the developments and how they might shape the future.
Thirty years ago, the world of travel was a far simpler place. There were no online travel agents; there was no seat-back inflight entertainment or in-car GPS. Mobile phones were brick-like, and could do little more than make calls ‚Äî using them for navigation was, at that point, unthinkable.
In the decades since, innovations in technology have completely transformed travel. Most recently, in September 2025, Apple introduced its latest AirPods, ushering in live translation capabilities to the earphones for the first time. Here‚Äôs how it‚Ä¶

entry.title: China welcomes Thailand-Cambodia truce ahead of trilateral talks
entry.summary: China on Sunday congratulated Cambodia on reaching a ceasefire with Thailand after weeks of deadly border fighting, as officials from the three countries prepared to open a two-day meeting in southwestern China.

entry.title: China's finance ministry says fiscal policies will be more 'proactive' in 2026

entry.title: Russia opposes Taiwan independence in any form, FM Lavrov says
entry.summary: Russia opposes Taiwan‚Äôs independence in any form and considers the island an inseparable part of China, Russia's Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said in remarks published on Sunday.

entry.title: Just opened‚ÄîUK's newest hotels to book for 2026
entry.summary:
These new hotels, opened in the last year, are where you should stay in 2026. The past year has seen a slew of exciting new hotel openings across the UK ‚Äî here‚Äôs where you‚Äôll want to book a stay in the new year.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
An old grand dame restored to its best, a literary hideaway in the heart of the city, a country retreat designed to escape the ordinary ‚Äî these accommodations across the UK represent the best of a thriving hotel scene welcoming exciting new arrivals each year. Whether you want to immerse yourself in country living, explore a storied coastline or upgrade your next city break experience, these new hotels are where you should stay in 2026.
Sitting at the end of a long driveway, with far-reaching vie‚Ä¶

entry.title: Follow the footsteps of champions in Italy's Winter Olympics host resorts
entry.summary:
Nordic combined is one of the Olympic disciplines that will be hosted in Val di Fiemme, along with cross-country skiing and ski jumping. This winter, Italy will host athletes from around the world at the Milano Cortina 2026 Winter Olympics. Here‚Äôs the lowdown on what‚Äôs new in the host resorts, what to see and where to ski in the footsteps of champions.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Faster, Higher, Stronger, Together. Not the title of a hitherto unreleased Daft Punk remix, but the new Olympic motto. Announced with great fanfare shortly before the last Winter Games, the addition of the word ‚ÄòTogether‚Äô to the century-old Latin formulation Citius, Altius, Fortius was meant to emphasise the International Olympic Committee‚Äôs commitment to public ‚Ä¶

entry.title: China issues drafts rules to regulate AI with human-like interaction
entry.summary: China's cyber regulator on Saturday issued draft rules for public comment that would tighten oversight of artificial intelligence services designed to simulate human personalities and engage users in emotional interaction.

entry.title: China passes revised foreign trade law to bolster trade war capabilities
entry.summary: China on Saturday passed revisions to a key piece of legislation aimed at strengthening Beijing's ability to wage trade war, curb outbound shipments from strategic minerals to sex dolls, and further open its $19 trillion economy.

entry.title: Here‚Äôs where NASA is looking for life in our solar system
entry.summary:
A composite view of Mars taken by the Viking I and II probes. From Viking to Perseverance, scientists have spent decades chasing chemical hints that could point to life beyond Earth.
In September, NASA announced the discovery of a possible sign of life, known as a potential biosignature, on Mars. The Perseverance rover, which has been exploring a dried-up lakebed for years, found traces of ancient redox reactions, which can be produced by either life or geological processes.¬†
Though the origin of the reactions remains unclear, the tantalizing discovery represents the latest chapter in the search for biosignatures on alien worlds. For a half-century, scientists have been fascinated and flummoxed by ambiguous compounds and structures on our neighboring planets‚Äîand increasingly, ‚Ä¶

entry.title: See 15 striking travel photos of 2025
entry.summary:
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Selecting the best travel images from a year‚Äôs worth of fantastic photography is quite a challenge when the photographers have travelled to all corners of the world to document features for National Geographic Traveller (UK). From the snowy peaks of Greenland and sun-kissed hills of Bhutan to the cowboys of Ecuador and lions on the prowl in South Africa, these images all capture natural moments of beauty, personality and culture from the world around us.
Ben Rowe, picture editor and Aisha Nazar, associate picture editor
A pride of lions in pursuit of a lioness who has strayed onto their territory at the Phinda Game Reserve in South Africa. Photographer Jonathan Gregson captured this encounter while on assi‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is there archaeological evidence for the Biblical fall of Jericho?
entry.summary:
The fall of Jericho is one of the most popular stories in the Bible. According to the Old Testament, Israelites‚Äîa group of Hebrew people whom Moses had led out of Egypt‚Äîconquered the city of Jericho in dramatic fashion: At the direction of God, they surrounded the city, blew on horns, and, with a little divine help, the blast was so powerful that it knocked¬†over the city‚Äôs heavy walls. The story showcased the might of God and argued that the Israelites were his chosen people.¬†
Jericho wasn‚Äôt just a biblical city. Modern Jericho still exists in Palestine‚Äôs West Bank and is popularly considered¬†one of the world's oldest cities. The ruins of Jericho‚Äôs ancient remains are located just outside the sprawling modern city center. These ancient remains are now the¬†UNESCO World Heritage¬†site Te‚Ä¶

entry.title: Inside the bone-crushing mating rituals of dinosaurs
entry.summary: An Olorotitan dinosaur fossil with fractured tail vertebrae has resurrected a theory around how dinosaurs mated. A handful of unique fossils are spilling the secrets of dinosaur courtship and reproduction.  Whatever happened to the duck-billed dinosaur, it was a real pain in the butt. Many of the spines sitting atop the animal‚Äôs tail vertebrae had been fractured. The dinosaur, known as Olorotitan to paleontologists, wasn‚Äôt simply clumsy; too many bones were broken. The breaks were more consistent with some heavy downward pressure right near the base of the tail. At 26 feet long and three tons, another Olorotitan would have been large enough to do such damage.¬† Institute of Natural Sciences in Brussels paleontologist Filippo Bertozzo had ventured to Blagoveshchensk‚Ä¶

entry.title: How travel will look in 2026‚Äîhere's what you need to know
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
This year is shaping up to be one of travel niches. Night owls will be embracing their dark sides and teetotallers will be enjoying juice pairings, while literary types will be looking to plan bookish getaways and runners will start lacing up in new¬†surroundings. Meanwhile, all-inclusives are making a comeback (with a difference), and more of us are set to experience life on the farm. Plus, AI ‚Äî and bot booking agents‚Äî will continue to transform the way we travel. These are the latest trends set to shape how we see the world.
For night owls, travel has never been more exciting. ‚ÄòNoctourism‚Äô, or nocturnal tourism, is booming, covering everything from stargazing and night-time safaris to after-dark city tours a‚Ä¶

entry.title: China eases IPO rules for firms developing reusable rockets
entry.summary: Chinese companies developing reusable commercial rockets will have access to a fast lane for initial public offerings on the tech-heavy STAR market that exempts them from some financial requirements, the Shanghai Stock Exchange said on Friday.

entry.summary: One United Nations peacekeeper was injured on Friday after heavy machine gunfire from Israel Defense Forces (IDF) positions south of the Blue Line, following a nearby grenade explosion, impacted close to a UN patrol in southern Lebanon.

entry.summary: The war in Sudan has been tearing the country apart for almost 1,000 days, putting the country‚Äôs health system under intolerable pressure. The World Health Organization (WHO) is reporting widespread disease outbreaks, severe shortages, malnutrition and rising deaths.

entry.summary: Nearly a month after Cyclone Ditwah tore across Sri Lanka, more than a million people ‚Äì including over half a million children ‚Äì remain in urgent need of humanitarian assistance, as floods, landslides and renewed rainfall continue to compound one of the country‚Äôs worst disasters in decades.

entry.summary: A paediatrician by training, Felipe Paullier has long been an advocate for youth. Formerly Director of the Uruguayan Government's Youth Institute, a role which involved several joint actions with various UN agencies, he was appointed to run the¬†UN Youth Office¬†in 2023, the youngest senior appointment in United Nations history.

entry.title: ASIA GOLD Record gold rally cools Indian buying; China discounts narrow
entry.summary: Gold discounts in India widened to their highest in more than six months this week as a relentless price rally curbed retail buying, while discounts in China narrowed sharply from last week's five-year highs.

entry.title: Asia stocks rise to six-week high; precious metals on a tear
entry.summary: Asian stocks rose to their highest in six weeks on Friday and a blistering rally in precious metals showed no signs of tempering as investors sought to close out the year on a high while a softer yen kept intervention risk in the fray.

entry.title: Japanese Cabinet approves record defense spending
entry.summary: Japan‚Äôs Cabinet has approved a record defense budget plan exceeding 9 trillion yen for the coming year.

entry.title: Inside London's most beautiful and unique private members' clubs
entry.summary:
The Library at The Reform Club, designed by Charles Barry in 1853 with an 1878 color scheme by his son, EM Barry. Getting access to London's private members' clubs is a rare occurrence for most people, but now you can see what these often-secretive spaces look like.
It‚Äôs hard enough to imagine getting inside London‚Äôs exclusive members‚Äô clubs, let alone being allowed to ogle all the details. Which is a shame, because some of the most memorable and important works of architecture and design in this historic city can be found behind these guarded doors.¬†
Few libraries can compete with the gasp-inducing beauty of the Athenaeum, and influencers would likely trample over each other to be allowed to shoot on many of the clubs‚Äô elegant staircases.
Luckily, a gorgeous new book,¬†Th‚Ä¶

entry.title: Explore S√°mi crafts on a road trip through Swedish Lapland
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With 24 saunas to 23 residents, it‚Äôs fair to say the village of Liehitt√§j√§ has at least one more sauna than is strictly necessary. Spend any time here, however, and you soon understand the ratio ‚Äî this is not, you‚Äôll see, a community that does things by halves.
Seventeen of those 23 residents belong to the same family, and I meet three of them one winter‚Äôs morning when the thermometer sits some way below zero and a gentle snowfall drifts from a leaden sky. It adds to the piles disguising the farm machinery and stacks of timber left in front yards, and introduces some extra peril to the clumps balancing precariously on the branches of spruce and birch. It‚Äôs a world of monochrome simplicity: white snow, dark trees, d‚Ä¶

entry.title: What is 'skimo'? It's the coolest new Winter Olympics sport
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
If you‚Äôve never heard of ski mountaineering before, you‚Äôre not alone. The competitive face of ski touring, this little-known sport involves climbing up a mountain then gliding down on skis, testing both the endurance and skill of enthusiasts. Scottish mountain guide Di Gilbert set out to popularise it in 2012, when she founded SkiMo Scotland ‚Äî the UK‚Äôs only company to organise ‚Äòskimo‚Äô races ‚Äî and began campaigning to get it recognised as an official speciality in the country. With the discipline soon debuting at the Milano Cortina 2026 Winter Olympics, it might finally get the attention she feels it deserves.
My mother ‚Äî northeast Scotland born and bred ‚Äî was quite formidable. I grew up in the countryside and was‚Ä¶

entry.title: China accuses US of distorting its defence policy in relation to India ties
entry.summary: China firmly opposes the U.S. Pentagon distorting its national defence policy, the foreign ministry said, referring to a mention of the development of China's ties with India in a report on the country.

entry.title: China says it hopes firms seek lawful, balanced solutions over TikTok deal
entry.summary: The Chinese government would like to see companies reach solutions that comply with Chinese laws and regulations and balance the interests of all parties, a commerce ministry spokesperson said on Thursday when asked about the hand-over of TikTok's U.S. operations.

entry.title: Foreign-branded phone shipments in China more than doubled on year in Nov, CAICT data shows
entry.summary: Shipments of foreign-branded mobile phones, including Apple's iPhones, rose 128.4% in China in November from the same month last year, according to Reuters calculations based on data released by a government-affiliated research firm on Thursday.

entry.title: China social media thrashes one-child policy after population control czar dies
entry.summary: The death of a former head of China's one-child policy has been met not by tributes but by castigation of the abandoned policy on social media this week.

entry.title: Looking for your next family adventure? Try an expedition cruise
entry.summary:
Between May and September, a group excursion with National Geographic-Lindblad Expeditions into Alaska‚Äôs Inian Islands archipelago guest-stars bald eagles and humpback whales. Who said expedition cruising was only for grown ups? Here are four family voyages for young explorers and conservationists.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With a growing number of tour operators and cruise lines offering intrepid family voyages, expedition cruising is no longer just for grown-ups. From following in the footsteps of Charles Darwin in the Gal√°pagos Islands to charting a course through Alaska‚Äôs wildest corners as part of National Geographic‚Äôs Explorers-in-Training programme, these expedition cruises offer young conservationists and budding adventurers the‚Ä¶

entry.title: The industrial waste site that glitters like a glacier
entry.summary:
As a travel content creator, Atul Chaurasiya is always on the lookout for unique and offbeat locations. When he came across videos of the Kishangarh Dumping Yard on YouTube, he decided to visit the site.
Located about 62 miles south of Rajasthan‚Äôs capital city Jaipur, Kishangarh is Asia‚Äôs largest marble market. At the city‚Äôs outskirts lies this marble industry‚Äôs dumpsite, a ‚Äúgenuinely beautiful‚Äù place, according to Chaurasiya‚Äîwhite mountains that resemble snow-covered peaks and a contrast to Rajasthan's otherwise arid landscape. The influencer created a reel about the location in September 2023, and the Instagram post garnered over 250,000 likes.

entry.title: A culinary revival is taking place in northern Poland‚Äîhere's why
entry.summary:
The Mot≈Çawa river is one of many waterways webbing the city of Gda≈Ñsk and testament to its seafaring legacy. On the Baltic Sea in Poland‚Äôs far north, the tricity region combines Hanseatic seafaring heritage with Polish, German and Kashubian cooking. centuries-old recipes are being revived and the city of Gda≈Ñsk celebrated with a ‚Äòculinary capital‚Äô designation.

entry.title: From ‚ÄòWatchers‚Äô to baby cherubs: A brief history of angel myths
entry.summary:
In ancient Judaism and early Christianity, angels were portrayed as powerful beings who guarded the Garden of Eden, chronicled the deeds of humans, and heralded the Messiah's birth. Far from the baby-cheeked cherubs of Renaissance art, they were fiery beings who inspired fear.
Angels are among the most comforting religious figures in the modern imagination, radiant winged beings who hover peacefully above Nativity scenes each December. Indeed, their presence in the Christmas story is integral to the unfolding of events. In the Gospel of Luke, the angel Gabriel announces both the birth of John the Baptist to his father, Zechariah, and the miraculous birth of Jesus to his mother, Mary. It is angels who proclaim ‚Äúgood news of great joy‚Äù to the shepherds under the night sky. And, criti‚Ä¶

entry.title: The evolutionary case for a little roughhousing
entry.summary:
Wolf pups at play at Zoo Acad√©mie, a zoo and training facility in Nicolet, Quebec, in 2017. Scientists are finding that rough play is important for animals and humans alike. A variety of studies are showing that rough-and-tumble play is important for animals and kids alike.
Gordon Burghardt kept a lion cub named Meg in his home at the behest of the Knoxville Zoo. To help Meg get out some energy, Burghardt and his wife would often play with Meg in their wooded, unfenced backyard. One day, a neighbor‚Äôs dog appeared, tail wagging. As an ethologist‚Äîa scientist who studies animal behavior‚Äî Burghardt could see that the dog was giving clear signals that he wanted to play, not fight, but would the lion cub be able to read them? After all, these are two creatures separated by around 45 mill‚Ä¶

entry.title: Who was Pliny the Younger? How his words survived Pompeii
entry.summary:
Eyewitness to the tragic fate of Pompeii. Nephew of a great naturalist. Trusted public servant. Friend of emperors. Famed chronicler of the culture and politics of ancient Rome.¬†
Pliny the Younger was all of the above‚Äîand his accounts of what life was really like in his era have withstood the test of time. The statesman and keen witness of daily life wrote careful collections of letters that offer a rare, detailed, glimpse into a bygone world. Still relied on by modern readers, Pliny the Younger‚Äôs observations of historic events and daily life give a precious look into Roman life. Here‚Äôs what to know about the Roman administrator and letter-writer‚Äîand why his words are still studied today.¬†
Born around A.D. 61, Gaius Plinius Caecilius Secundus was the son of a wealthy famil‚Ä¶

entry.title: Democrats urge Trump to reverse mass ambassador recalls
entry.summary: Democratic senators urged President Donald Trump on Wednesday to reverse a recall of nearly 30 career ambassadors, warning the move leaves a dangerous leadership vacuum that allows adversaries like Russia and China to expand their influence.

entry.title: China's LandSpace hopes to complete rocket recovery in mid-2026
entry.summary: Chinese rocket developer LandSpace plans to successfully recover a reusable booster in mid-2026, a company executive said in an interview, underscoring the Beijing-based firm's ambition to become China's answer to SpaceX.

entry.title: Industrialisation without destruction: A UN blueprint for the future
entry.summary: Since the 19th century, industrialisation has had a transformative effect on the world, both positive and negative. It has created jobs and lifted millions out of poverty. But it has also had devastating consequences; destroying ecosystems, polluting the air, and driving the climate crisis that threatens to make large parts of the planet uninhabitable.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Humanitarian response ongoing despite restrictions
entry.summary: Although ‚Äúsignificant restrictions and impediments‚Äù continue to hamper humanitarian operations in Gaza, teams are still responding to the population‚Äôs needs, the UN aid coordination office OCHA said on Wednesday.

entry.title: Paper and wood: Forest products show signs of recovery, UN agency says
entry.summary: From wood-based panels used in construction, to charcoal for cooking food, forest products are valued and traded all around the world.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Historic vote looms in Central African Republic as UN urges peaceful participation
entry.summary: With Central Africans set to vote in presidential, legislative, regional and long-delayed municipal elections this weekend, the United Nations has appealed for calm and restraint, warning that the credibility of the process will be critical to consolidating peace after years of conflict and instability.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN celebrates 10 years of progress in youth, peace and security agenda
entry.summary: The UN has long been at the forefront of efforts to involve young people in decision-making, and the last decade has seen significant progress, thanks to the adoption of a Security Council¬†Resolution on Youth, Peace and Security which led to widespread changes in the ways that the voices of young people are not just heard, but also incorporated in peace plans and policies.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DOGE claims against reality
entry.summary: The farce that was DOGE made claims of heavy savings and government efficiency.‚Ä¶ Tags: DOGE, government, New York Times

entry.title: Thai and Cambodia militaries hold talks on resuming ceasefire
entry.summary: Sixteen days of border clashes have killed at least 86 people.

entry.title: Southeastern Taiwan shaken by 6.1 magnitude quake, no immediate reports of damage
entry.summary: An earthquake with a magnitude of 6.1 struck Taiwan's southeastern coastal county of Taitung on Wednesday, the island's weather administration said, although there were no immediate reports of damage.

entry.title: China's farmers are up to their ears in milk
entry.summary: Beijing's decision to apply tariffs on EU dairy imports may help.

entry.title: Tim Cook doubles his stake in Nike, shares rise
entry.summary: The Apple CEO, who has been on Nike's board since 2005, represents a vote of confidence in CEO Elliott Hill's efforts to revive demand.
